Just discovered that we do need to change tox.ini because of the way the ensure_tox role and ensure_tox_version var are implemented for zuul.  If tox is already present, it gets used, regardless of the value of ensure_tox_version.  The ensure_tox_version var is only used when tox is not present and needs to be installed.  This will be a problem for any devstack-based jobs, because by the time we get to run our tests, there's all sorts of opportunities for someone else to install an undesirable tox.  But as long as we say what tox version we want in the 'requires' in tox.ini, we should be ok.

So, things that bug me about this approach:

- load() is a complete mess -- we've basically scrapped all attempts at making a versioned file format from v1 and done yet another completely incompatible thing. https://xkcd.com/927/
- New format gets a new name -- which seems appropriate given how it's no longer a gzip stream, but it (1) makes the auto-reloading tricky, especially when trying to auto-reload through the transition and (2) will require more significant changes to any ring-management tooling operators are using (such as our controller).

That said, I do like the accessibility via standard tooling -- I have high confidence that I could build a ring without ever needing to touch swift code if I wanted.
this looks pretty snappy!

I have to admit i like this slightly better than having to write our own unzip cli https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/866082

I'm curious what other blockers and concerns you have for this approach:  upgrades? 
 zipfile overhead/speed/acceleration?  cross-platform-support?

IDK that I'm opposed to having our own zip-like util -- if you're interacting with rings at this level, it seems likely that you're going to need swift installed anyway.

Upgrades and automatic reloads are one set of worries -- if we have both a .ring.gz and a .ring.zip around, which gets loaded? Should it always prefer the .zip, or should we compare mtimes? If one of the two is invalid, should we try to load the other? Maybe only if the mtime indicates we're not going back in time?

The other is the required updates to operator tooling -- with the other chain, ops get an extra CLI flag, but nothing else should need to change. With this one, they need to know which which filename they're generating to make sure their (updated) tooling can copy out the proper ring, and clean up the old format once nodes get the new one. Then do all that in reverse if they discover they need to roll back.

> When passing a ZipInfo instance as the zinfo_or_arcname parameter, the compression method used will be that specified in the compress_type member of the given ZipInfo instance. By default, the ZipInfo constructor sets this member to ZIP_STORED.

*shrug* I'm not sure it makes that much of a difference -- this function's still going to be a mess of special cases with no coherent story. At least with the custom format, we can use the format_version we already created.

swift/common/ring/utils.py.message: is this a copy of the whole array - or some sort of memory view object?

It's calling tobytes() on the underlying large array -- so there's one copy of array -> bytes before handing off to zipfile to do its thing, rather than N array -> bytes copies for each replica, plus an additional copy to join them all together.

Maybe if we basically rewrote ZipFile.writestr() ourselves we'd have a way to use array.tofile() and avoid even that copy? (Or at any rate, punt it to stdlib to manage.) But the existing APIs feel really limited: https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/v3.11.0/Lib/zipfile.py#L1828-L1831

I think we can go a little further than Christian R.'s comments do. Consider this. If the assume that the argument for having static keys is solid, and the rotation is mandatory, having just two keys may not be enough if the keys are used to encrypt the data. The data gravity makes it infeasible to re-encrypt everything when keys roll.

So, as Christian said, we need to consider encrypting only a small amount with static keys - a metadata or a superblock if you will - and then store actual data keys there. Then, it may be possible to update these metadata or superblocks when keys roll. Note that we must supply the redundancy for the list of data keys. Also, it must be encrypted in a smart way: for example, not have a magic number that can provide a known plaintext to an attacker. It must have a checksum that allows us to know if/when the supplied static key decrypts correctly.

I am against judgements like "not a best policy" and appeals to unspecified authority (recommended by whom?). I prefer sticking to facts with something like: "Encrypting data stored in a public cloud adds an additional layer of protection beyond the access controls of the provider."

Rather than decreasing the worry, I would rather decrease the risk due to specific attack vectors such as the compromise at the provider. The existing wording about "anyone having data readable" is sufficient, although I would replace "sensitive" with "backup". If you want to link the sensitivity level with decision-making, it needs to be explicit (e.g. sensitive data - encrypt it; not sensitive - dump it naked with 1 layer of protection by authorization).

I don't think the single key is going to fly. It is essential to change keys. See the comments by Christian Rohmann about primary/secondary, and most importantly, only encrypting a metadata store (which can be re-encrypted upon a key roll-over).

In the proposed change, we mention only GCS and S3 to support this encryption but here we mentioned chunked backup drivers. Posix driver also inherits from ChunkedBackupDriver and NFS driver inherits from Posix driver.
My confusion is, are we supporting this for any driver inheriting from ChunkedBackupDriver or specifically for GCS and S3? I understand GCS and S3 backups are stored remotely so we need this extra layer of protection but trying to understand the implementation.
below (L#71) we mention "on" and here we are describing "always", i think "on" goes better with "off" so we can modify this to "on"
nit: backups

I'd align the Fernet key management with how Keystone does it (https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/zed/admin/fernet-token-faq.html#what-are-the-different-types-of-keys) and have a primary and also a secondary key to allow for key rotation.

Also having the keys as dedicated files (like Keystone) might make it easier "sync" or otherwise handle them in config management.

1. I still stand with my argument to allow for a possible key rollover. Otherwise a single key would have to live forever. A big no no in cryptography.

2. But I am wondering if Fernet is really a good fit for this use case and how it would actually be applied for backups and their chunks?
 
 a) Fernet is meant for "tokens", so small pieces of data. That data is not only AES encrypted but also receives an HMAC (SHA256) and will then be base64 encoded (see https://cryptography.io/en/latest/fernet/#cryptography.fernet.Fernet.encrypt)

 While the HMAC might be a addition to ensure the integrity and authenticity of the  remotely stored data, base64 encoding will create lots of additional overhead.

 See this issue with performance numbers included:  https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/issues/4953

 b) Fernet documents that the message has to fit into memory (see: https://cryptography.io/en/latest/fernet/#limitations), this is somewhat limiting the chunk size and is likely not very efficient. Gorka mentioned that Pete Zaitcev was looking into using streaming IO for backups - something I have looked into as well. Using Fernet encrypt() method would also hinder these kind of improvements, compared to using a "streaming" AES encryption for example.
 
 c) Or am I misunderstanding how you intended to apply Fernet?
I haven't looked into Fernet's implications for streaming of backups yet. In fact, I didn't account for the upcoming encryption work.

Maybe just using Fernet and their keys to encrypt the remotely stored metadata would work. The metadata could then contain the actual (symetric, AES) key used to encrypt the backup data. It's stored with the metadata when it's uploaded and it's read back (and decrypted via Fernet) on restore.

This is somewhat similar to how Restic does it (see https://restic.readthedocs.io/en/stable/100_references.html#keys-encryption-and-mac) storing "JSON documents which contain all data that is needed to derive the repository’s master encryption and message authentication keys from a user’s password".

barbicanclient/v1/secrets.py.message:
I don't think we should show the consumers here. Since this representation is used everywhere in the CLI, then outputting the entire list of consumer dicts here would make the output of `openstack secret list` unreadable.  It would be better to add a new subcommand instead: `openstack secret consumer list $SECRET_ID` that can list all consumers only for that specific secret.

If we do want to have different columns here, then we should revisit the idea of making these strings match the API names exactly.  e.g. "secret_ref" instead of "Secret href".  It would make it easier on users to have uniform naming for both the CLI and the Python API.  It would also be better for scripting since you wouldn't be required to quote the columns that have spaces to address them. i.e.

    `SECRET_PAYLOAD=$(openstack secret get --payload $SECRET_ID -c secret_ref -f value)`

instead of

    `SECRET_PAYLOAD=$(openstack secret get --payload $SECRET_ID -c "Secret href" -f value)`

specs/2023.1/approved/ironic-shards.rst.message:
In discussing with John, we're concerned there may be dragons in the compute manager.py code, specifically centered around compute node's destroy() method being called when a compute node does not appear in the list. The reason we're concerned here, and ultimately we need to carefully walk the compute manager code as it interacts with the nova.virt.ironic driver, is to ensure that we don't end up in a situation where we somehow, mid-upgrade, accidentally cause compute node records to be destroyed.

Granted, we believe the nova-manage command should repair/heal the compute node records because it provide a upgrade/migration means which also automatically heals the pitfalls.

tl;dr carefully check nova/compute/manager.py and nova/virt/ironic/driver.py and make sure people won't have super bad things happen with ComputeNode records.

Felipe and I were chatting about this; and we feel that this doesn't really address the root cause here. The bug mentions that a significant number of snapshots went "missing" on a busy storage cluster. unit_tests/test_rabbit_utils.py.message: nit: can be replaced with policy, see #L1430, no need to read the dictionary again.
This isn't clear why mode='nodes' is broken. Can we elaborate why its broken here and what needs to be done to resolve this?

I've rebased this change as well as addressed the problematic node scenario. I've additionally tweaked/streamlined the code within set_ha_mode which should still address all the various scenarios while adhering to the original goal of the patchset.

So, firstly this code path is actually never used, it's existed since forever, but set_ha_mode is never called with anything other than ha_mode=all.

Secondly the current JSON for 'nodes' is broken in two ways
(1) since ha-sync-mode was added in 2016 by 5d1528e7da8caa4fe8a3508585f2e3559f69984f. The closing } brace is in the wrong spot after [%s] instead. So it's invalid and won't work.
(2) Even if you fix that, it tries to create a node list using the string [%s] and then adding the string ha_params.join(","). You can never generate valid JSON with this because if you pass in an array the node names are not quoted as required by JSON and if you pass in your own string, since it calls .join(",") on the value passed in you get a comma between every character.

I thought about fixing but but instead I want to restructure that entire function to generate the JSON using the json library instead of manually constructing JSON with string interpolation. Then we can remove duplciation by just adding entries/modifyign the json based on the conditionals rather than having the items all repeated for each mode. But I didn't want to submit that as part of the same change to make it more easily reviewable as it would make it much less clear how this change is working.

Let me know if you'd prefer to:
- Have me updated the commit to clarify the comment with why it's broken
- Submit a change rewriting set_ha_mode as mentioned before, or after, this change is merged
- Merge that change into this patchset
- Just merge the current patch as is

Note: I also thought about just deleting the other un-used modes but there is also a changeset queued to add quorum queues to this function so if I had of done that we'd just add more back later. But I guess that's still an option.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
That's an open door to broken host imho, and a lot of useless support... There are some constraints with installed packages on the host vs container.
IMHO, the right way would be: scale out, run update.
This would ensure consistency across the deployed OC.

Another solution would be to update the OC image before they are used for new hosts. That should be easily possible, especially for cases where CU are using satellite or any other tool ensuring consistency across packages on an infra.

i'm not sure about this. for one, package update is necessarily related to satellite registration, i'm not sure we want this logic here. also, we can't just allow operators to update packages whenever as it typically requires some orchestration. what if they unexpectedly pull a new kernel?

i understand they have to opt-in to this variable, but it's also likely operators could forget they have it set in an environment file.

i think there are a lot of unknowns here. However the end result is not all that different from using pre-deployed nodes with a base image and satellite, and getting the latest packages on a deployment. I'd still want to see some input from update/upgrades here if this feature is something they want to take on supporting, as I think just adding it to this role feels a little backdoor'ish.

Well it's mostly our customers using Satellite or Capsules that are requesting this in order to avoid a perhaps minor update after scaling nodes ... As they argue that they might have to reboot the nodes after and that after the first boot and registration I think we usually reboot at deployment time, this would probably install at most a few packages that would have been added to their satellite view because of async releases that are not always included in the overcloud image.   I feel the same way about this change as you do and I'm concerned about operators forgeting about this setting and installing more packages than they would really have wanted to install but the thing is, they're really adament of this feature.  We can drop it if you'd prefer.

A few questions:
 - Is there a bug associated with this patch? If not, should there be one? The topicality of this patch hints that it is meant to address an issue.
 - Why not add to all neutron containers? I could see some logic in having just the API, or just the agents, but not the API and only one of the agents.

I did open a backport request for queens [1] which was denied because queens is EOL (which is fine) and this patch here would've allowed them to bypass the paunch dance we had to do to add SYS_PTRACE in the contrail / neutron containers.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1902793

Well I had a case with a customer where they needed to enable this for running gdb (or something like that) in a container and they needed extra capabilities .  They wanted something like that and we managed to hardcode it in the tht for them but I felt like we needed something more granular on a wider scale and this was a PoC for me and them.   Let me see if I can find back that support case and see if I created a BZ at that time.

deployment/neutron/neutron-api-container.message: This would be global which doesn't seem like a good idea

I was flirting with this idea and I didn't think of any good ways of actually doing this.  We have an issue with one process which has a memory leak and needed to add SYS_PTRACE to the capabilities of a neutron-like container and this was a PoC on how we could probably do it.   Role-specific might not be really practical if I need to change this only for neutron-server or neutron-ovs-agent across the board.   I think this usecase is a corner case that won't happen much but still is a "valid" one.   If a customer wants to add a capability, either he does it globally or on a per service/docker definition.  I'm not sure how this could be implemented practically.
do you mean this should become "role_specific", right? I'd agree.

At least role specific, however this would be for *any* service that includes this which could be dangerous or cause problems.  It seems like it should role specific and service specific but at the very least it should probably be role specific.
Role specific would work for neutron-server and neutron-ovs-agent if they are the same role. The issue I have here is really the blanket change this would be if adopted.

cap_add doesn't like an empty value :

2021-11-13 18:33:06.601170 |                                      |    WARNING | ERROR: Can't run container neutron_api
stderr: Error: "CAP_[]": unknown capability
Or maybe this is a kolla bug ?

if you intend to make this role_specific, then you need to add the resource for RoleParametersValue that does the value merging.

https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/role_specific_parameters.html
Condition should also check for RoleParameters for the presense of NeutronContainerCapabilities

Role-specific values are valid only when there is a possibility for the service to be present in multiple roles, In case of neutron-api service, it will be present only in the controller roles, which is unique. No value in having role-specific for controller services.

NeutronApi can be on separate role but it cannot be on multiple roles. The use case for role-specific is to provide different values for different roles where the service is hosted, like

parameter_defaults:
  Role1Parameters:
    NeutronContainerCapabilities: value1
  Role2Parameters:
    NeutronContainerCapabilities: value2

Do you think such a scenario is applicable for NeutronApi Containers?

What about this ?

parameter_defaults:
  ComputeParameters:
    NeutronContainerCapabilities: value1
  ControllerParameters:
    NeutronContainerCapabilities: value2

I mean , I just added it to this NeutronApi but what about NeutronOvs and NeutronL2Agent ?  NeutronSRIOV ?  It's just a first step and we didn't need it in other containers at the time of that patch ... but it doesn't prevent anyone from re-using this code in other services as well.   I do see why we dont' really need it in neutron-api but when I first wrote this patch, I had all neutron services in mind which can be scoped on roles as well.    Is that really bad that this one doesn't support it ?  I can still just move the role-specific code in ovs-agent and remove the tag here and map-merge.  It's not really complex ... should we do this instead ?

Ok. It is prefered to keep the parameter non-role-specific when a service can be used in only one role. This NeutronApi service can be used in one role only. It doesn't have a value in creating a role-specific merging in this service. But if the same parameter is required in the ovs-agent service, then it can be implemented as role-specific. By doing that, the same parameter will have two different implementations, which may confuse users. So it is better to have role-specific implementation in this service too, eventhough it does not add value to keep it consistent with usability.

You can put NeutronApi on separate role if you want ... this would still stand.   Also, this was needed on the compute and was only a PoC for a customer which needed to troubleshoot some issues with ovs (from memory) but I expect more people having to troubleshoot different type of issues in different containers family so ... it's a nice to have on all containers in all roles to be able to override the Containers Capabilities .
It would be better to have NeutronContainerCapabilities itself instead of vars.
This value need to be fetched from the merged resource RoleParametersValue

After merge of manila backup spec, updating PR to address spec comments.

FYI, Steps to test on devstack :-
1. Create share of 1 GB. e.g. name it tmp_backup. Export location of share (admin) is then added in /manila/data/drivers/nfs.py config option 'backup_share'. e.g. 10.1.1.100:/shares/share-5c8bba9f-18ad-4e64-801e-204575e7a97a
2. Add host IP in manila/data/helper.py config option 'data_node_access_ips' and restart manila service
3. Add access-allow with ip type and value (controller node IP) to above temp share(tmp_backup). e.g. '10.1.1.50'
4. Create another share (e.g. share1) of 1GB, mount it, write some data to share. We will take backup of this share into tmp_backup in next steps.
5. openstack share backup create share1 --name backup1
6. mount tmp_backup and check the content. It should be same as data added in step4.
7. unmount tmp_backup. Mount share1, delete its data and unmount it.
8. openstack share backup restore backup1
9. Mount share1 and and check the content. It should be same as data added in step6
10. unmount share1
11. openstack share backup delete backup1.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
nova-ssh is not primarially for remotefs

it is there to provide a secondary ssh server for live migration so that libvirt/qemu data can be tunneled over ssh.

in more recent releases kolla support native tls with libvirt 
https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/blob/master/doc/source/reference/compute/libvirt-guide.rst#libvirt-tls

however in the absence of that the nova ssh container is present to provide a seconday ssh server that has keys exchanged so that the qemu instance can comunicate using netcat or the virt-ssh-helper to tunnels the unix socket data.

has this been tested with the rsync remote fs driver.

nova has two remotefs drivers one based on rsync and the other based on ssh

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/5d66c8963418e34e0643147215ca70bb2d857545/nova/virt/libvirt/volume/remotefs.py#L200

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Is that still required?

we have a similar script in rdo which is not maintained by the nova team and reluctantly supported by redhats compute team
https://github.com/rdo-packages/nova-distgit/blob/rpm-master/nova-migration-wrapper

we would remove it if we were allowed as ocationally changes to libvirt break compatiblity.

if kolla was to proceed with this chnage it would take on the responciblity of ensuring the wrapper conitnues to work going forward which may or may not be something you want to do.

in general the securit model of openstack is such that if you cant trust those who have ssh access to the host systems you cant trust the cloud.

this might improve security in a limited way but there isnt a vector from nova to allow any kind of user input to be passed to the ssh command so in practice this is not closeing any security vuldernablity that exists form an openstack level.

if the ssh private keys that are generatd for each host are leaked this might reduce the impact of someone using that key but honestly im not sure how useful this is to add vs providing it as a template override example that some one can implement themselves fi desired.

docker/nova/nova-ssh/remote_fs.message:
this assuming it is true is an internal implementtion detail of how it currently works and not an api contract. nova is free to chnage that if we wanted too without notice. with that said i dont think it would be likely that we would change it.

if we did however it wold not be a bug in nova if this wrapper broke it would be a kolla bug at that point.

nova does not really use rootwap anymore. the rootwap profile nova has is just for os-brick we do not use rootwrap for nova itself.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/etc/nova/rootwrap.d/compute.filters

this is the rootwap config we ship today which only allows the privsep deamon to run
since rootwrap is deprecated building new code on that infrastructure is generally not recommended.

im pretty sure we use chown for the vtpm data and we may also use daxio for pmem/nvdimm support its possibel we dont actullly chown the vtpm data via ssh and do that instead via the compute agent in the dest but not sure about that…

later
—————
it looks like we chown the vtpm data seperatly but we do use rsync for the rsync driver which i think can tunnel over ssh. 

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/5d66c8963418e34e0643147215ca70bb2d857545/nova/virt/libvirt/volume/remotefs.py#L200

so you proably at least want to test that before considring this.

nc and virt-ssh-helper also likely need to be in the list.

docker/nova/nova-ssh/remote_fs.sh.message: Is there a way we could just execute the command passed without a shell? Perhaps if we wrote this in python and used subprocess?

I think the difference with a python subprocess is that you could run it without a shell, so you don't need to worry about special characters - they can only run a single command. If we happened to miss a special character here it could open up a hole. OTOH, if the command has one of these characters legitimately, e.g. in a weird fs path, we'll break it.

I am not really sure to be honest.  The idea was that if someone had gotten into the nova-ssh container, we are trying to prevent them from being able to move effortlessly across hv's.  So its possible that a crafty person could figure out what commands are allowed and simply get a passing first command but tack on all sorts of other possible things to do badness.  So we dont want to run just the original unfiltered command, assuming that the first command was ok, so the whole thing is ok.

I assume similar gotchas will apply with python + subprocess.  I wasn't really able to find any examples of people doing this in python.  But bash/perl seemed to be the most widely used.
What does this command do? Maybe a comment to explain?

Did you try these? I think they might need to make the command something like this to actually get a shell:

ssh <host> bash -c '<command>'

I might be wrong there.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: @Sergii, this is in response to your feedback on fully automating all the conversion required for train-wallaby upgrade. This adds the heat-nic-config -> ansible-j2-config step to the `openstack overcloud node export provisioned` command. Since this command run as part of undercloud upgrade, all the yaml definitions for 'network provision', 'vip provision' and 'node provision' + converted nic-configs will be in the working-dir for each overcloud stack after upgrading the undercloud.
Adding Brendan who had some experience using the conversion script.

Are we sure we want to do this? If we expect customers to not have old nic config templates (which they should), I would prefer we extract it from stack in the old format and expect customers to migrate them manually. My understanding is that the conversion script we provide is best effort, customer has to validate the converted templates before using.

Forgot to mention about usage of UNSUPPORTED_HEAT_INTRINSIC_FUNCTIONS (in the coversion script) like yaql in many customer nic configs.

IMHO, this does not necessarily improve user experience (i.e Looks like we don't raise any error and will write string[1] in the converted file when we encounter those functions and user would mostly not look at them). My point is we've the script and we document users to use it if that helps. There are plenty of steps in upgrade process already i.e not talking about a one click upgrade.

Having said that, not blocking it. We can merge it if we want like many other things:)


[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/tools/convert_heat_nic_config_to_ansible_j2.py#L329

My suggestion:
1) copy the script to nic coversion path
2) use --yes as we should be idempotent even if this is one off action


diff --git a/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_node.py b/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_node.py
index e92fae81..387ef3cf 100644
--- a/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_node.py
+++ b/tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_node.py
@@ -551,6 +551,10 @@ class ExtractProvisionedNode(command.Command):
 
         j2_nic_conf_basename = (heat_nic_conf_basename.rstrip('.yaml') + '.j2')
         j2_nic_conf_path = os.path.join(j2_nic_conf_dir, j2_nic_conf_basename)
+        convert_script_path = os.path.join(j2_nic_conf_dir, 'convert_heat_nic_config_to_ansible_j2.py')
+        shutil.copy('/usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates/tools/'
+                    'convert_heat_nic_config_to_ansible_j2.py', convert_script_path)
+        os.chmod(convert_script_path, 0o750)
 
         tmp_net_data_fd, tmp_net_data_path = tempfile.mkstemp(suffix=".yaml")
         try:
@@ -559,8 +563,8 @@ class ExtractProvisionedNode(command.Command):
             with open(tmp_heat_nic_conf_path, 'w') as tmp_heat_nic_conf:
                 tmp_heat_nic_conf.write(heat_nic_conf_content)
 
-            cmd = ['/usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates/tools/'
-                   'convert_heat_nic_config_to_ansible_j2.py',
+            cmd = [convert_script_path,
+                   '--yes',
                    '--stack', stack.stack_name,
                    '--networks_file', tmp_net_data_path,
                    tmp_heat_nic_conf_path]

Personally I am not big fan to incorporate such conversions to tripleoclient. Firstly, this operation is one time only so after T>W upgrade we'll need to clean up the code from tripleoclient. I would prefer something like tools/merge-new-params-nic-config-script.py which can be called any time.
We're probably underestimating the kind of stuff I've seen customers do in nic config templates ex. add port resources and use their attributes.

Late to the party. 

Yeah, I think we might want to test it with a few of the more complex templates to make sure we are absolutely confident. The last thing we would want is to break networking during the FFU process.

But, in saying that. You have added a warning to inform the user that we have tried to convert their existing template to the new format, and they need to review it. 


I think from a user experience perspective, this is going to be a confusing process - converting from Heat template to Jinja2. So this at least gives the user an idea of what the conversion looks like. We aren't just defaulting to use the file without first informing the user, so they should definitely be reviewing it to ensure there are no unexpected changes being made.

To Rabi's point. I definitely can see some edge case nic-config template that is going to cause us issues; I've seen some weird things. We may be underestimating the spread of nic-config variants in the wild.

But, the counter argument there I think is that we might be underestimating the customer experience and comfort with both Heat and jinja2. I can definitely foresee a lot of calls for help during this process. So anything we can do to reduce the burden for our users during this process. I think would be worth considering.

I'm inclined to vote in favour of this, with the expectation that we make sure we document this specific change as well. Informing users that we will try our absolute best to convert their existing templates, but they should review the output and also review the document on networks-v2 should there be any confusion whatsoever.

Lately with some experience using the conversion script it is actually quite solid. 

I'll add Brendan who used the conversion script when "updating" the Doc teams env.

Also we do put text with capital letter warnings[1] in the exported bm_nodes.yaml file which is also displayed on stdout. This is an attempt at removing the "run command" step, but keeping the "review the result" step.

So I suggest that we:

1) Abandon the other three patches:

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/manila/+/858214/
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/manila/+/858225/
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/manila/+/858226/

2) Rebase this change against "origin/master" (``git rebase -i origin/master``) and remove the dependency on the other changes (in the editor that shows up, delete the other commits that predate this, save and quit)

3) Update this change to fix up the commit message and include a release note. Here are some instructions on how to generate a release note with a template: https://docs.openstack.org/manila/latest/contributor/adding_release_notes.html#how-do-i-add-a-release-note

Delete all sections, retain the "fixes" section and add what was fixed.. perhaps something like:

 "The POST /shares API now validates that the share type specified is a string

4) Add this file to git, and improve the commit message here to what you had in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/manila/+/858214/ --- do this with "git commit --amend" instead of just "git commit".

5) Make sure that the Change-Id in the commit message remains the same: Ia28e40c507ff649d57993434207481eaa17bf2a7 - and this should be the last line or section in your commit - just like what's seen below. 

Then you can push up your fix with "git review" and it should create "Patchset 2" under this very change...

Again, thanks a lot for your work :) Hope you're having a great GHC!

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I don't think this is a good idea. This test suite is for Octavia and not individual providers. We have discussed this at one of the Octavia meetings and decided it was not a good idea. This is why we have been working to remove any of the provider specific code that was added.

Here are a couple of reasons I can think of off my head:
1. Our test jobs already run up against the maximum runtime allowed in zuul, so we would not be able to use this in opendev zuul.
2. It confuses what this test suite is for, Octavia, and not a specific provider driver.
3. It will confuse users about where to report bugs with the third-party provider drivers. I.e. they should not report test failures caused by a specific provider driver to the Octavia team, but instead to the provider driver owner.

We just run multiple jobs, each with all of the supported providers enabled, each configuring tempest to use the provider under test.
This way the test UUIDs are consistent (again, testing Octavia and not a provider).

Thanks for the review Michael. 

I would argue that 1 is not a valid reason not to extend the number of tests for Octavia.
For points 2 and 3, this patch does not make it easier or harder to test third-party providers. It only makes it easier to test multiple providers, but they should be tested anyway if they are used in a production environment.

I do get the point that we are testing Octavia itself and not necessarily the individual providers. From a practical standpoint, however, this is also the perfect tool to perform validation testing on Octavia instances, at which point we are not only interested in Octavia itself but also its compatibility with the providers we intend to use. If someone wants to use multiple providers, they should be able to test that.

Anyway, I don't want to beat a dead horse. If this decision is made then I will implement this downstream somewhere instead.
This probably deserves a release note

removed descriptions for keystoneauth as this library strongly depends on Keystone and is not reasonable to change it for the external authorization server support.

specs/keystonemiddleware/2023.1/external.message:
I think that if you use v3 externaloauth2 password, you need to add the following configuration items:.
```
   export OS_AUTH_URL=http://127.0.0.1/identity
   export OS_USER_ID=333e5ae19cbb47e8b18969306582be25
   export OS_PASSWORD=devstack
   export OS_PROJECT_ID=6890f5679f304671aba65dfd4e9b11f5
```
Otherwise, you will not be able to retrieve catalog and the openstack command will not work correctly.
In this case, I think you will also need to configure the authentication methods allowed by the external authorization server.
```
    export OS_EXTERNAL_OAUTH2_AUTH_METHOD=client_secret_basic/client_secret_post/client_secret_jwt/private_key_jwt
```

> you will not be able to retrieve catalog 

Just a question. As I mentioned in [1], I assume the situation where a OpenStack service is deployed as a standalone service. Do you think we need service catalogs in this situation?


[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/keystone-specs/+/861554/3/specs/keystonemiddleware/2023.1/external_authentication_server_oauth2_grant_support.rst#19
I think this setting is unnecessary.

In the case of jwt, aud (Audience) and exp (Expiration Time) claims are required, so I think it is necessary to add the following setting in addition to the setting described here.
```
audience=https://<keycloak_host>:<port>/realms/<realm_name>
jwt_bearer_time_out=3600
```

I think this setting is unnecessary because a client certificate is considered to have been used with mTLS.
If you need to add a setting, it should have a different name as the parameter name conflicts with line 250.

Regarding the setting of auth_method=tls_client_auth, I stated in the previous comment that I think it is unnecessary, but as a result of the investigation, I understand it is necessary, so I would like to withdraw my comment.
I think auth_method should support the following five authentication methods:.
```
tls_client_auth
client_secret_basic
client_secret_post
client_secret_jwt
private_key_jwt
```
Do both the v3externaloauth2password (described in line 183) and v3oauth2token authentication types need to be added to keystoneauth?
``v3externaloauth2password`` is an alternative. So, I'm not intend to support both types.

I think OS_AUTH2_ACCESS_TOKEN needs to be added as a setting item.
OS_TOKEN is the Token used to retrieve catalog from keystone, and OS_AUTH2_ACCESS_TOKEN is the token obtained from the external authorization server.
As I mentioned in [1], I assume the situation where a OpenStack service is deployed as a standalone service. Do you think we need service catalogs in this situation?

Or similar to HA subnet ("_create_ha_subnet"), HA network ("_create_ha_network") or HA port ("add_ha_port")

Actually I would revert [1] to keep all auxiliary ports outside any project. Those ports (or resources) are automatically created or deleted by the system, not the user. Those resources could be listed by non-admin users but not handled (delete).

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/446878

The difference with FIP agent gateways and others you mention is that this port is taken from the subnet allowed address pool, just like a DHCP agent port.

Moreover, we are relying on the project_id to monitor the ports assigned to a specific customer, ports without any project_id are really hard to identify.
